Service Animals

How "Service Animal" Is Defined

Service animals are defined as dogs that are individually trained to do work or perform tasks for people with disabilities. Examples of such work or tasks include guiding people who are blind, alerting people who are deaf, pulling a wheelchair, alerting and protecting a person who is having a seizure, reminding a person with mental illness to take prescribed medications, calming a person with Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) during an anxiety attack, or performing other duties. Service animals are working animals, not pets. The work or task a dog has been trained to provide must be directly related to the person's disability. Dogs whose sole function is to provide comfort or emotional support do not qualify as service animals under the Americans with Disability Act (ADA).

This definition does not affect or limit the broader definition of "assistance animal" under the Fair Housing Act or the broader definition of "service animal" under the Air Carrier Access Act.

Some State and local laws also define service animal more broadly than the ADA does. Information about such laws can be obtained from the State attorney general's office.

Where Service Animals Are Allowed

Under the ADA, State and local governments, businesses, and nonprofit organizations that serve the public generally must allow service animals to accompany people with disabilities in all areas of the facility where the public is normally allowed to go.

Service Animals Must Be Under Control

Under the ADA, service animals must be harnessed, leashed, or tethered, unless these devices interfere with the service animal's work or the individual's disability prevents using these devices. In that case, the individual must maintain control of the animal through voice, signal, or other effective controls.

Inquiries, Exclusions, Charges, and Other Specific Rules Related to Service Animals

  • When it is not obvious what service an animal provides, only limited inquiries are allowed. Staff may ask two questions: (1) is the dog a service animal required because of a disability, and (2) what work or task has the dog been trained to perform. Staff cannot ask about the person's disability, require medical documentation, require a special identification card or training documentation for the dog, or ask that the dog demonstrate its ability to perform the work or task.
  • Allergies and fear of dogs are not valid reasons for denying access or refusing service to people using service animals. When a person who is allergic to dog dander and a person who uses a service animal must spend time in the same room or facility, for example, in a school classroom or at a homeless shelter, they both should be accommodated by assigning them, if possible, to different locations within the room or different rooms in the facility.
  • A person with a disability cannot be asked to remove his service animal from the premises unless: (1) the dog is out of control and the handler does not take effective action to control it or (2) the dog is not housebroken. When there is a legitimate reason to ask that a service animal be removed, staff must offer the person with the disability the opportunity to obtain goods or services without the animal's presence.
  • People with disabilities who use service animals cannot be isolated from other patrons, treated less favorably than other patrons, or charged fees that are not charged to other patrons without animals.
  • Staff are not required to provide care or food for a service animal.
audioDescription: A large brown building with National Park signage sitting in front of a large sandstone wall.

title: Placer Point
listingDescription: Placer Point is a peaceful bend in the river which can have a small beach area dependent on the flow of the Green River.

images.altText: Ripples in a river as it flows towards colorful cliffs in the distance.
images.title: Green River at Placer Point
images.caption: Placer Point provides a peaceful place to enjoy the Green River.

bodyText:
A short side road leads to a bend in the Green River called Placer Point. The name refers to an effort in the 1930s to dredge and sluice gold from the river bottom. The gold particles were too fine to extract profitably and the operation eventually folded.

Today, Placer Point is a pleasant spot to enjoy the Green River. People use this point to fish (state fishing license required) or visit a nearby sandy beach that is exposed when river flows are low to lounge by the river. Small water craft like canoes, kayaks, or paddleboards can either be launched or retrieved from this site. This is also a good spot for birwarchers. In some years, peregrine falcons have nested in the cliffs across the river.
audioDescription: From the parking area, you can see the Green River Winding around a long bend. A short trail leads to a sandy beach with river levels are lower. In spring, the beach may be covered by water. Tall orange and yellow cliffs rise across the river. The area is covered by a variety of grasses and low shrubs.

title: Plug Hat Butte Picnic Area
listingDescription: Enjoy some light hiking and scenic vistas from the top of Plug Hat Butte. This wheelchair-accessible area is pet-friendly and perfect for a picnic lunch!

images.altText: The western view from Plug Hat Butte overlooking canyons.
images.title: West View from Plug Hat Butte
images.caption: Plug Hat Butte provides scenic overlooks high above Bull Canyon.

bodyText:
Perched atop an outcropping of Entrada sandstone, the Plug Hat Butte Picnic Area offers a perfect getaway from the busier side of the park. Here, visitors can enjoy an elevated view of Bull Canyon, as well as an excellent vantage point for western-sky stargazing. 

The picnic area provides tables, grills, and wayside exhibits. Vault toilets and a trash receptacle are available in the parking lot. Leashed pets are allowed in the Plug Hat Butte area, but owners must clean up after them. The area features 3 pet-friendly hiking trails. The Plug Hat Picnic Area Trail and the Plug Hat Trail are both paved and wheelchair accessible, although some assistance may be required. The 1.3 mile Bull Canyon Rim Trail is located beyond the gate at the back of the picnic area, and is not wheelchair accessible. It runs along a cliff with extreme drops, so keep children and pets close. Visitors must pack all trash out of the picnic area. Do not feed wildlife!
audioDescription: The Plug Hat Butte picnic area is located about 7 miles north of the Canyon Visitor Center on the Harpers Corner Road. The Picnic Area is located on the western side of the road. The Plug Hat Trail is on the eastern side. The parking lot is a loop, offering spaces for passenger cars as well as RVs. At the center of the loop, there is a small restroom building with vault toilets inside, and a trash receptacle outside. Across from the restroom is the picnic area, under the shade of juniper and pinyon pine trees. Picnic tables and benches are located at scenic locations along Plug Hat Picnic Area Trail, which has two access points from the parking lot. Each picnic spot provides a table and a small grill. The trail runs along the edge of a fenced-in cliff. The cliff offers overlooks of Bull Canyon from above. The canyon is mostly yellow sandstone, with rough desert plants blanketing the surface. A wayside exhibit near the fence shows a photo of the same scene under a clear blue sky. Text labels on the various cliffs denote the name of each rock formation. The exhibit reads, "BULL CANYON OVERLOOK. You are standing on the northern edge of the Colorado Plateau, a region of dramatic landscapes shaped by geologic uplift and erosion across Colorado, Utah, Arizona, and New Mexico. As with most of the Colorado Plateau, this view is dominated by sedimentary rock layers that formed hundreds of millions of years ago. Some began as deposits on ocean floors, others were formed by sand dunes in vast deserts. Uplift of the plateau brought a diversity of ancient environments back up to the Earth's surface as colorful rock layers. Clues to their origins are contained within the unique patterns and fossils of each formation." A square of text along the bottom of the wayside describes the various rock layers, "NUGGET SANDSTONE: 190 million years ago, this region was a vast desert with shifting sand dunes. Dinosaur footprints are occasionally found in this sandstone, as are diagonal cross-beds. CARMEL FORMATION: 180 million years ago, the ocean inundated the desert, leaving behind dark red silt and mud. ENTRADA SANDSTONE: 170 million years ago, sea level dropped and the ocean retreated to the west. Coastal currents deposited sand along the beach and winds built the sand up into dunes. MORRISON FORMATION: 150 million yeard ago, rivers deposited mud and sand over a flat landscape dotted with ponds, trees, and ferns. Dinosaurs roamed the river floodplains." On the right-hand side of the exhibit, there is a stratigraphic column showing the order of the rock layers with their labels. It says, "23 different rock layers record the story of change in this area's life and landscapes through time." Arrows pointing towards layers in the upper third of the column let the reader know that they are standing atop a bluff of Entrada Sandstone, and that the Dinosaur Quarry Exhibit Hall is located in the Morrison Rock Formation. Gates of Lodore, which is located at the far northern end of the park, is part of the Uinta Mountain Group (the oldest layer at the bottom of the column). At the very back end of the picnic area is a gate with a hiker symbol on it. Opening the gate will lead you to the Bull Canyon Rim Trail, which is unpaved and uneven. A sign displays the logos of the Bureau of Land Management and the National Park service. There are maps showing the location of the out-and-back trail. From left to right, the text boxes read, "Reduce your impact. This trail is open to foot traffic only. Please stay on the designated trail. You will help protect this Wilderness Study Area by reducing impacts to sensitive soils and preventing the creation of redundant user-created trails. Welcome to the 1.3 mile Bull Canyon Rim Trail. This out-and-back foot trail begins and ends at Dinosaur National Monument's Plug Hat Butte Picnic Area, but is located primarily on public lands managed by the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) within the 12,300 acre Bull Canyon Wilderness Study Area. This cooperative partnership between the National Park Service and the BLM provides a seamless opportunity for you to enjoy your public lands. The Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 directed the BLM to inventory and study roadless bureau-managed lands for wilderness characteristics. Areas found to have specific characteristics outlined in the act are managed as Wilderness Study Areas to not impair suitability for designation as wilderness until the U.S. Congress makes a final determination on the area. WARNING: This trail is located in close proximity to cliffs with extreme drop offs along the entire trail. Please ensure that children always remain a safe distance from the cliff edges and be aware of your surroundings at all times, especially at the viewpoints. You are responsible for your own safety."

quickFacts.value: Scenic Overlook, Picnic Area, Pet Friendly, Accessible
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Plug Hat Trail
listingDescription: Looking for easy-to-access views of Dinosaur's scenic canyons? The Plug Hat Trail is paved, pet-friendly, and wheelchair accessible. Enjoy informative signs and benches at scenic spots along the way.

images.altText: Informational sign and paved path at the Plug Hat Trailhead.
images.title: Plug Hat Trailhead
images.caption: This paved trail offers accessible views of Dinosaur's rugged landscape.

bodyText:
Located on top of a butte, the Plug Hat Trail offers panoramic views of the surrounding landscape. The trail is paved and winds through a forest of pinyon pine and Utah juniper trees. Signs along the way provide information about the local community of plants and animals. Benches are available at scenic spots. Although the trail is wheelchair accessible, some assistance may be needed. A wheelchair-accessible picnic area is located across the road from the trailhead.

Length: 0.25 miles (0.4 km) round-trip

Level of Difficulty: Easy. The trail is paved and even.

Trailhead Location: Off of the Harper's Corner Road, about 5 miles (8 km) north of the Canyon Visitor Center.

Your Safety: Be prepared for desert hiking. Take a hat, sunscreen, and water. Let someone know where you are going, and when to expect you back. Wear comfortable shoes, such as hiking or athletic shoes. Use caution near cliffs! Keep children and leashed pets close by.

Rules and Regulations:
  • Leashed pets are allowed on this trail, but you must clean up after them.
  • Carry out all trash.
  • Collecting artifacts, fossils, plants, antlers, rocks, or other objects is prohibited.
  • Do not feed or approach wildlife.
  • Biking is not permitted on this trail.
audioDescription: From the start of the trailhead, the informative signs along the trail read as follows: "JUST ENOUGH FOR TOUGH TREES. Juniper and pinyon trees dominate this community of plants and animals. Below 6,000 feet in elevation, winter-cold air inversions limit juniper survival. Above 7,000 feet, winter temperatures of long duration limit juniper and pinyon growth. The higher elevation traps more winter snow and summer thunder showers than in the desert shrub community. This extra moisture is just enough to allow juniper and pinyon trees to flourish." [A diagram shows a simple illustration of a mountain, with lines denoting the elevations and associated plant communities. It lets the reader know that they are standing in pinyon pine and juniper forest habitat between 6,000 and 8,000 feet.] "UTAH JUNIPER (It is not a cedar). Mule deer browse juniper leaves in the winter, and the woodland provides protective winter habitat. Pinyon pine grow more successfully where pioneering junipers provide a shady and cooler micro-climate. Connections abound in the juniper and pinyon pine forest. Evergreen foliage attracts insects and wary birds who nest in junipers and eat the insects. Juniper berries are eaten by jackrabbits, birds, and coyotes. The hard seeds survive animal digestive tracts and are dispersed in their droppings. Inspect the tree's scale-like leaves. Small, wax-covered leaves prevent the loss of excessive moisture. Use your nose to smell the aroma." [This older metal sign has images of plants, animals, and text scattered all over it. The animals shown include: mule deer, pinyon jay, jackrabbit, western bluebird, plain titmouse (bird), common bushtit (bird), evening grosbeak (bird), and coyote.] "PINYON BED & BREAKFAST. The pinyon pine and juniper forest supports many creatures. Can you think of predators that eat the insects, mammals, and birds dependent on this woodland? If the pinyon and juniper woodlands were lost, how could you suffer? Pinyon needles use solar energy to convert air, water, and minerals into plant material (food for some). Food and shelter is provided for more dependent creatures that are part of the web of life. Pinyon nuts are eaten by pinyon mice, cliff chipmunks, bushy-tailed woodrats, black bears, and people. Phloem (part of the bark that moves nutrients up the tree) is eaten by porcupines in winter and larvae of bark and engraver beetles. Dianthidium bees build their hive in pine pitch tucked into bark fissures or beneath rocks. Xyla sawfly larvae subsist on plant pollen until they are ready to drop to the ground where they burrow into the soil to pupate. Pinyon needles are browsed by mule deer and eaten by a resident sawfly, Neodiprion edulicolus." [This sign offers illustrations of all the animals mentioned in the text.] "MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL, MUTUALLY DEPENDENT. Hidden in the aroma of the pinyon woodland is a unique natural dependence. Pinyon nuts feed the birds and the birds plant the tree. Pinyon jays nest in juniper, pinyon, and ponderosa pine. Flocks of pinyon jays and Clark's nutcrackers wheel and sweep through the woodland, harvesting the pinyon nuts. Seeds are buried at the flock's traditional nesting area. Incubating pinyon jay females subsist on cached nuts, as do nestlings. Not all the cashed nuts will be eaten; some will sprout to perpetuate the woodland. Around the end of August, seeds in the green, pitchy, and tightly closed cones ripen. The presence of green cones actually stimulates testis development in male pinyon jays at the right time for late summer breeding. Up to 20 seeds can be temporarily stored in the jay's elastic throat, and 95 seeds can be stored in a special pouch beneath the nutcracker's tongue for transport." [This sign displays illustrations of pinyon jays and Clark's nutcracker, along with an image of the green pinyon cones.] "CHOICES. Nature provides commodities which support jobs. Some people believe the pinyon and juniper woodland acreage is wasted unless livestock graze and fence post are harvested. Some believe preserving the pinyon and juniper woodland has its own intrinsic values, providing silence, maintaining biological diversity, and continuing plant and animal relationships. What do you think? As a consumer of nature's commodities, you should decide!" [This older metal sign has 3 illustrations. The top shows yellow bulldozers felling the forest. The bottom left shows a lumberjack cutting a pine with a chainsaw. The bottom right shows a lizard beside a beat up soda can, half-buried in the dirt.]

quickFacts.value: Hiking Trail, Wheelchair Accessible, Pet Friendly
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Pool Creek Petroglyphs
listingDescription: A thousand years ago, the Fremont Culture left their marks in the rocks at Pool Creek. The site provides a great opportunity to reflect on the long legacy of indigenous culture here.

images.altText: A series of organized holes and etchings form images in the rock face.
images.title: Pool Creek Petroglyphs
images.caption: These dotted designs at Pool Creek haven't been found anywhere else in the monument.

bodyText:
Look carefully. The petroglyphs at Pool Creek can be difficult to find. Along the Echo Park Road, a sign directs visitors down a short trail where a sheer cliff stands opposite a creek. Carved into the cliff about 35 feet (10.5 m) above ground level are several figures. The ancestral indigenous people of the region created these petroglyphs approximately a thousand years ago. But how did they place their designs so high up? Back when these petroglyphs were first carved, the ground's surface extended to the level where the petroglyphs are now. Over the last thousand years, water flowing in the creek channel on the west side of this canyon eroded that access, leaving the petroglyphs where we see them today.

Don't touch! Petroglyphs and pictographs are fragile, irreplaceable records of the past that many still hold sacred. Touching them can leave skin oils behind, and tracings or rubbings can ruin the designs. Federal law protects all artifacts, including these sites. Do your part to respect and protect the past, and report any vandalism you find.
audioDescription: In the area where you park, the Echo Park road is a rust red color. A sign that says "Petroglyphs" has an arrow directing visitors down a short dirt trail surrounded by trees. Be careful! At the end of this trail, there is a small creek with no fence. Beyond it, a sheer red rock face stands tall. It is stained with gray-black streaks, known as "desert varnish." Approximately 35 feet (10 meters) up the rock face from where the ground is today, several clusters of organized pockmarks form images. Upon careful inspection, they appear to be human-like figures with ornate clothing. These are the Pool Creek petroglyphs. There are two waysides in this area. The one on the left is larger. The main image is a black and white drawing of two indigenous people using tools to create the petroglyphs. The person on the left stands, while the one on the right kneels on a large rock. The main text reads: "Out of Reach. Carved into the cliff face high above are several human-like figures, each with what appear to be elaborate headdresses or necklaces. Approximately a thousand years ago, the Fremont Culture created these petroglyphs. How did they do it? Today the petroglyphs are inaccessible, but this wasn't always the case. When the Fremont made these images, the ground surface extended to the level of the petroglyphs, approximately 35 feet up the cliff face. Over the last thousand years, the water flowing in the creek channel on the west side of this canyon has eroded that access, leaving the petroglyphs high above human reach." On the right side of this wayside, there's closeup image of one of the petroglyphs. It's a cluster of carved dots, which branch out on either side. Beneath it are several etched squares arranged in a semi-circular pattern. A label pointing to the dots says, "Dot-pattern design." A label pointing to the squares says, "Chipped design." Below it, more informational text reads: "Each of these petroglyphs includes many small holes drilled into the sandstone cliff. Within Dinosaur, this dot-pattern design is only found here at Pool Creek. Fremont Petroglyphs were often made by chipping away sections of rock to create a shape or an outline. This style can be seen in the lower part of the petroglyph above." In the lower right of this same wayside, a black bar issues the warning: "These fragile designs can never be replaced. Do your part to protect them. Do not touch: the oils on our hands erode the petroglyphs. Do not trace or rub the petroglyphs: the soft sandstone rock is easily damaged." To the right of the larger wayside, a smaller, older one displays a map. It indicates the relative locations and shapes of the petroglyphs in the rock face 35 feet above where the sign's viewer would stand.

title: Quarry Entrance Station
listingDescription: Entrance station located on the Utah side of the monument.

images.altText: A dinosaur with its head out the window
images.title: Fee Staff at Dinosaur National Monument
images.caption: Fee staff at the monument are ready with information in addition to collecting entrance fees

bodyText: The Quarry Entrance Station is where monument staff collect entrance fees and sell park passes.
audioDescription: A small stone building with brown metal roof that sits in the middle of the road.

title: River Trail - Green River Campground Trailhead
listingDescription: Trail follows the Green River, connecting the Green River and Split Mountain Campgrounds. It provides dramatic views of Split Mountain. Wildlife is frequently seen along the river including mule deer and a variety of birds.

images.altText: A dirt trail moving along the banks of a flowing river towards large sandstone cliffs.
images.title: River Trail
images.caption: The River Trail provides views of both the Green River and Split Mountain.

bodyText:
Trail follows the Green River, connecting the Green River and Split Mountain Campgrounds. It provides dramatic views of Split Mountain. Wildlife is frequently seen along the river including mule deer and a variety of birds.

Length: 1.5 miles one way / 3 miles round trip. Not a loop.

Level of Difficulty: Easy - Moderate.

Trailhead Location: North end of Green River campground in A Loop, or south end of Split Mountain campground.

Your Safety: Be prepared for desert hiking. Take a hat, sunscreen, and water. Let someone know where you are going, and when to expect you back. Wear comfortable shoes, such as hiking or athletic shoes. Keep children and leashed pets close by. Use caution near drop offs and along river banks.

Rules and Regulations:
  • Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Please pick up any pet waste and deposit in a trash receptacle.
  • Carry out all trash.
  • Collecting artifacts, fossils, plants, antlers, rocks, or other objects is prohibited.
  • Do not feed or approach wildlife.
  • Biking is not permitted on this trail.
audioDescription: A dirt trail walking alongside the banks of a flowing river towards large sandstone cliffs.

title: Ruple Point Overlook
listingDescription: Ruple Point rewards hikers with a stunning look at Split Mountain as the Green River carves its way through.

images.altText: A view peering down into a canyon where a river carves through.
images.title: Ruple Point
images.caption: Ruple Point overlooks the Green River carving open Split Mountain

bodyText:
The end of the Ruple Point Trail rewards those who make the journey. Hikers are able to experience the breathtaking view of Split Mountain Canyon and the Green River 2,500 feet (762 meters) below.

While Riple Point technically lies on the Utah side of the monument, it can only be accessed from the trailhead off of Harpers Corner Road on the Colorado side of the monument.
audioDescription: A panoramic view of a river carving through a canyon.

title: Ruple Point Trail
listingDescription: For most of its length, Ruple Point Trail crosses a rolling terrain filled with sagebrush and juniper. Near the end of the trail, a short descent rewards hikers with a breathtaking views of Split Mountain Canyon and the Green River 2,500 feet (762 meters) below.

images.altText: A vast overlook looking into a mountainous canyon with a river cutting through.
images.title: Ruple Point Trail
images.caption: The Ruple Point Trail ends in a dramatic look down Split Mountain Canyon.

bodyText:
For most of its length, Ruple Point Trail crosses a rolling terrain filled with sagebrush and juniper. Near the end of the trail, a short descent rewards hikers with a breathtaking views of Split Mountain Canyon and the Green River 2,500 feet (762 meters) below.

Length: 4.1 miles one way / 9.2 mile round trip. Not a loop. 

Level of Difficulty: Moderate to difficult. Trail may be difficult to follow in some areas.

Trailhead Location: Island Park Overlook on the Harpers Corner Road, 27 miles north of the Canyon Visitor Center. (Note: while the trail itself lies within Utah, it can only be accessed from the Colorado side of the monument.)

Your Safety: Be prepared for desert hiking. Take a hat, sunscreen, and water. Let someone know where you are going, and when to expect you back. Wear comfortable shoes, such as hiking or athletic shoes. There is very little shade except at the very end of the trail. The trail is hard to follow as you descend at the end. Use caution around the cliffs at the end of the trail. This is mountain lion and black bear country. Keep small children close.

Rules and Regulations:
  • Pets are not allowed on this trail or in the backcountry.
  • Carry out all trash.
  • Collecting artifacts, fossils, plants, antlers, rocks, or other objects is prohibited.
  • Do not feed or approach wildlife.
  • Biking is not permitted on this trail.
audioDescription: A rugged trail moving through sagebrush and juniper trees ending in a dramatic overlook into a canyon with a river carving its way through.

title: Ruple Ranch
listingDescription: In 1882, Henry and May Ruple began homesteading in Island Park and developed a cattle ranch. Now the remains of their ranch stand looking towards Split Mountain.

images.altText: A small wooden cabin in a grassland area dotted with trees looking towards a mountain.
images.title: Ruple Ranch
images.caption: Ruple Ranch was once a cattle and sheep operation.

bodyText:
In 1882, Henry and May Ruple began homesteading in Island Park and developed a cattle ranch. The Ruples' son, Hod, took over the property in 1915. Later, Hod Ruple and his family switched from cattle ranching to sheep ranching. The property remained in the Ruple family until 1945.
 

Although the family's original house burned in 1960, the corrals and loafing shed found on the site today were used in the Ruples' ranching operations.
audioDescription: A small wooden cabin in a grassland area dotted with trees looking towards a mountain. There are old wooden fence posts and corals left behind from the abandoned ranch.

title: Scenic Drives
listingDescription: Scenic Drive category

images.altText: The Harpers Corner Road snakes back and forth around a rock face.
images.title: Harpers Corner Road
images.caption: The paved Harpers Corner Road is winding and steep in some places.

bodyText: Even though much of Dinosaur National Monument is managed as wilderness, a network of roads penetrate the monument's rugged interior. These scenic drives provide access to dramatic views, a chance to see wildlife, or the ability to deeper explore the area by hiking one of the monument's trails. Some of the roads are paved two-lane highways – fine for any passenger car – while others are dirt roads requiring the use of a 4-wheel drive, high clearance vehicle. Some monument roads close for the winter. Always check the weather before heading out on any of the monument's dirt roads. Due to the clay soils, some roads may be impassible when wet.
audioDescription: Numerous roads provide access to areas within the monument. Some are paved roads suitable for all vehicles. Others are unpaved roads where high clearance vehicles are recommended.

title: Sound of Silence Trail
listingDescription: A hike through several of Dinosaur's interesting rock layers, illustrating the monument's geologic diversity. Sweeping views of Split Mountain. Some steep sections on slickrock.

images.altText: A pair of hikers in a sandstone clearing pointing off into the distance.
images.title: Sound of Silence
images.caption: Sound of Silence trail offer solitude amongst stunning landscapes.

bodyText:
A hike through several of Dinosaur's interesting rock layers, illustrating the monument's geologic diversity. Sweeping views of Split Mountain. Some steep sections on slickrock. This trail ties in with Desert Voices Trail via a ¼ mile connector trail. 

Length: 3.2 mile loop.

Level of Difficulty: Moderate to difficult. Trail may be difficult to follow in some areas.

Trailhead Location: Approximately 2 miles east of the Quarry Visitor Center on the Tour of the Tilted Rocks auto tour road.

Your Safety: Be prepared for desert hiking. Take a hat, sunscreen, and water. Let someone know where you are going, and when to expect you back. Wear comfortable shoes, such as hiking or athletic shoes. There is little to no shade on the trail. Use caution on the slickrock section. This is mountain lion and black bear country. Keep small children close.

Rules and Regulations:
  • Pets are not allowed on this trail or in the monument's backcountry.
  • Carry out all trash.
  • Collecting artifacts, fossils, plants, antlers, rocks, or other objects is prohibited.
  • Do not feed or approach wildlife.
  • Biking is not permitted on this trail.
audioDescription: A roadside pullout with a trailhead sign next to a dirt trail winding towards different colored sandstone cliffs.

title: Sound of Silence Trail Stop 1

images.altText: An expansive view of rolling hills with multi-colored sandstones exposed.
images.title: Dinosaur's Geologic Layers
images.caption: Dinosaur National Monument has 23 exposed geologic layers.

bodyText:
Dinosaur National Monument is best known for its dinosaur fossils, but it protects so much more. 23 geologic layers are exposed in the monument, spanning more than one billion years of Earth's history. Sparse vegetation reveals these layers that tell us about the distant past.

Look to the west and view geologic layers through time. Frontier Formation and Mowry Shale to the south (on your left) are younger rock layers, dating to the late Cretaceous, approximately 98 million years ago. The Nugget Sandstone to the north (on your right) is much older, extending back to the Triassic, 200 million years ago. In front of you is over 100 million years of climatic and environmental change.

Change can be continuous and slow or incredibly quick in a desert environment like this. Soon you will encounter an intermittent stream bed (referred to as a wash). It is often dry, but water roaring downhill after intense thunderstorms can rapidly reshape the landscape.
audioDescription: An expansive view of rolling hills with multi-colored sandstones exposed.

title: Sound of Silence Trail Stop 10

images.altText: An open desert landscape with a view of a large craggy mountain in the distance beneath a blue sky.
images.title: Split Mountain Vista
images.caption: Split Mountain stands dramatically amongst the titled rocks.

bodyText:
What is happening beneath our feet to result in such a dramatic landscape at the surface? The noticeable curve of Split Mountain is part of an anticline - an upward fold of rock. While Split Mountain arcs up, other features seem to sag. The sags are called synclines. This underlying rollercoaster of rock formed when formerly flat sedimentary layers were compressed and wrinkled. Forces related to the building of the Rocky and Uinta Mountains 70 - 40 million years ago caused the uplifting, tilting, faulting and folding of the rock layers. While some layers erode into mounds, others stick out as ridges. 

Erosion reveals not only a variety of shapes, but also an array of colors. Look back across the Moenkopi Formation labyrinth you just traversed. In the distance you will see a swath of red rock known as “The Racetrack.” The “lanes” are made up of Triassic-aged Moenkopi and Chinle formations, seemingly wrapping around the corner. These rust colored rocks are rich in iron and are sometimes called the Triassic Red Beds. Iron is also responsible for many of the yellow, orange and greenish tints to the rock layers here. Obviously inspired by the colors and shapes from near this ridge, Ernest Untermann brought his paints and easel to this area in the mid-1900s. A German immigrant, he became known as “The Artist of the Uintas,” and Dinosaur’s dramatic landscapes spoke to him. The sedimentary rocks around you were originally flat, horizontal layers when they were deposited. Each layer represents its own story of a different past environment, different fauna and flora, a succession of time and life on our planet. For millions of years, these stories were buried deep underground. Thanks to uplift and erosion, they are once again free to tell colorful tales of change over time.
audioDescription: An open desert landscape with a view of a large craggy mountain in the distance beneath a blue sky.

title: Sound of Silence Trail Stop 11

images.altText: Reddish-brown soil that appears crusty in texture covering the desert landscape.
images.title: Biological Soil Crust
images.caption: Biological soil crusts are extremely sensitive and take time to form.

bodyText:
Soils in an arid environment are fragile. Take a minute here to inspect the crusty biological soil. It is mostly cyanobacteria (sometimes called blue-green algae), and also includes lichens, mosses, green algae, microfungi and bacteria. It takes many years for this soil to form and support life. While cyanobacteria are mobile and will regenerate if disturbed, lichens and mosses are not, and will die if trampled. Blown by wind or moved by other forces, it is estimated that lichens will recolonize an area in 45 years, while it takes mosses an estimated 250 years. These crusts control erosion and fix nitrogen, helping other plants to grow. Please stay on the trail to help preserve these unique soils.

All around you is Ephedra viridis, commonly called Mormon Tea because it was used by early Native Americans and settlers to make an invigorating tea. It is an important browse crop for livestock and also deer, elk, and sheep, especially in the winter months. The large seeds are a good protein source for small mammals and birds. The drug ephedrine, an antidepressant and decongestant, can be extracted from this and other Ephedra species. This area is a great place to look for animal tracks, scat, and game trails. Can you distinguish between carnivore and herbivore scat? Look for fur and bones in the long, slender pieces of mountain lion, coyote, and bobcat scat. Deer, elk and rabbit scat will be more smooth and rounded. You may see game trails in this area, made primarily by elk and deer. See if you can distinguish these game trails from the people trail you are following!
audioDescription: Reddish-brown soil that appears crusty in texture covering the desert landscape.

title: Sound of Silence Trail Stop 12

images.altText: A small green shrub-like tree standing amongst reddish sandstone rocks.
images.title: Utah Juniper
images.caption: Utah Junipers provide important habitat in the high desert.

bodyText:
This spot provides a place to rest, rejuvenate, and cool down before climbing the rocky ridge ahead. Solitude and refuge are two things that national parks and monuments offer. These are places to reflect, learn, and experience nature. Also protected are other qualities such as dark night skies and natural quiet — rare commodities in cities where many of us live. Growing around you on the slope are Utah junipers. The most common tree species in Utah, it covers one-fifth of the land area of the state. It seems like they can grow nearly anywhere, even out of solid rock. Their roots are the secret. A massive system that makes up 2/3 of the tree’s total mass, the tap root can be 25 feet deep and lateral roots may extend out 100 feet. The juniper berry is actually a tiny pinecone, and is eaten by rabbit, fox, coyote, and many species of birds. Junipers grow slowly. Older trees, which may be 650-850 years old, have sculptural qualities. Even dead, a juniper may stand silent and strong for several hundred years. Like all of the plants at this 5,000 foot elevation, the juniper must survive on a sparse 10 inches of precipitation a year.

As you hike, check out the sky and you may see a Turkey Vulture or two, flying on silent wings high above you. Lightweight for such a wide wingspan, they teeter and totter on the breeze, rarely flapping their wings. An excellent sense of smell leads Turkey Vultures to carcasses where they feed cooperatively. Think of these silent birds not as purveyors of death, but rather as elegant birds who transform death into life on the wing. Look carefully at each soaring bird and you may be lucky to see a Golden Eagle, easily confused with a vulture at first glance. The Golden Eagle, at 10 pounds, is a much heavier bird, outweighing the vulture by 6 pounds. Eagles do not teeter and totter, and they hold their wings out flat, while vultures hold their wings in a slight V-shape. Both are dark birds, the vulture is here only during the summer, the eagle a year-round bird. Perhaps a lizard has caught your attention during your hike, lending even more life to the desert. Six species of lizards are found here:
sagebrush, plateau, western whiptail, shorthorned, side-blotched and tree lizard. Listen for lizards rustling about in the leaf litter, looking for spiders or insects to eat.
audioDescription: A small green shrub-like tree standing amongst reddish sandstone rocks.

title: Sound of Silence Trail Stop 13

images.altText: An expansive view atop a beige sandstone ridge with scattered desert shrubs growing throughout.
images.title: Green River Landscape
images.caption: Higher portions along the trail overlook the Green River in the distance.

bodyText: In the distance to the south you might be able to pick out the Green River. This source of water in the desert attracted not only the Fremont and Ute people who once dwelt here, but before them, people going back 10,000 years. Petroglyphs, pictographs and former dwelling sites dot the landscape. John Wesley Powell boated through here on his way down to the Colorado River about 150 years ago. He made natural history observations, mapped the area, and named many features. The Green River remains a source of adventure and sustenance today.
audioDescription: An expansive view atop a beige sandstone ridge with scattered desert shrubs growing throughout the landscape.

title: Sound of Silence Trail Stop 14

images.altText: A small shrub-like tree with one leaf per stem growing on red, rocky soils on top of a ridge.
images.title: Singleleaf Ash Tree
images.caption: Singleleaf Ash trees are unique to the American Southwest.

bodyText: On this ridge, take a moment to rest in the shade of the small Singleleaf Ash tree, a species unique to the American Southwest. Surviving by means of deep roots and sheer perseverance, they often take on a dwarfed appearance. Unlike most species of ash trees, which have compound leaves, this western ash has a single leaf on each stem. The red rock ridge underneath you is the Chinle Formation, formed during a time when rivers, marshes, and small lakes covered the landscape. Plants would not have included a flowering tree like the Singleleaf Ash. Instead, conifers, cycads, ferns, and horsetail plants grew here. Dinosaurs made their first appearance in this time period, about 225 million years ago. Coelophysis, a three-toed, therapod dinosaur about the size of a large dog, roamed the land. Large crocodile-type creatures called phytosaurs lurked in the waters. Imagine how different the sounds of the Triassic would be from the sounds of today!
audioDescription: A small shrub-like tree with one leaf per stem growing on red, rocky soils on top of a ridge.

title: Sound of Silence Trail Stop 15

images.altText: Smooth sandstone bluffs and cliffs rolling across red rock desert landscape.
images.title: Red Rock Country
images.caption: Dinosaur National Monument encompasses the northernmost region of "Red Rock Country."

bodyText: For those feeling fit and adventurous, an optional side trip is available at this spot. Climb the sloping rock stretching to the sky to the west. Step carefully, move slowly, and when you reach the top, you will be rewarded with a 360° panorama. Alternatively, you can enjoy the view from the shade of the juniper tree beside the trail marker, and contemplate that you are standing at the northern edge of the Colorado Plateau. Encompassing 240,000 square miles, this area is sometimes known as “Red Rock Country” and centers on the Four Corners area where Colorado, Arizona, Utah and New Mexico meet. There are 27 National Parks and Monuments, 30 wilderness areas, millions of acres of National Forest and many other protected areas in this high desert region of the plateau. Dinosaur National Monument is the northernmost of these parks. Each place has a unique contribution to the story of the southwest.
audioDescription: Smooth sandstone bluffs and cliffs rolling across red rock desert landscape with small trees and shrubs scattered throughout.

title: Sound of Silence Trail Stop 16

images.altText: A small canyon in between two smooth sandstone cliffs with various types of desert flora growing.
images.title: Sound of Silence Scenery
images.caption: The beauty of the landscape has great meaning to many people.

bodyText: For many of us, the simple beauty of the land’s colors and textures may be enough to satisfy, awe, and inspire. These places also allow geologists, paleontologists, biologists, and archeologists to more deeply investigate and study the Earth and our history. On this hike, you have seen the silent reminders of many changes —sometimes occurring over millions of years, or sometimes occurring very quickly. Sediments, rocks, plants, animals, and the other features of the landscape all speak to those who slow down and take the time to hear what they have to say.
audioDescription: A small canyon in between two smooth sandstone cliffs with various types of desert flora growing in between.

title: Sound of Silence Trail Stop 2

images.altText: A dried up streambed acting as a trail winding through desert shrubs.
images.title: Sound of Silence Streambed
images.caption: Portions of the trail wind through dried up streambeds.

bodyText:
Many sections of this trail never look the same way twice, and this wash is a good example of constant change. Water is a powerful force that shapes soils as well as rocks. Water can build as well as erode. Plants nourished by water soften the landscape and make it possible for animals, birds, insects, and reptiles to live here. Listen and watch for signs of life as you proceed.

Signs of animals include the game trails that elk and deer create as they crisscross the washes that the Sound of Silence Trail follows. Don’t be tempted to follow these tracks up and out of the wash though — they will lead you through some rough territory!
audioDescription: A dried up streambed acting as a trail winding through desert shrubs.

title: Sound of Silence Trail Stop 3

images.altText: A singular large leafy tree with rough bark shading over a dried up streambed.
images.title: Sound of Silence Cottonwood
images.caption: The lone cottonwood on the trail provides welcome relief from the sun.

bodyText: You might expect a large Fremont Cottonwood tree like this to grow near a more obvious source of water. What does its presence here tell us? The surrounding rocks funnel seasonal rainwater to its thirsty roots. This tree, with leaves that sing and whisper in the breeze, provides habitat for birds and insects, and shade for all. Rabbits, deer, and elk feed on its shoots and stems. Insects live on it that are food for birds. Hawks and bats may use cottonwoods as sites to nest or roost. Even in death, tree cavities are refuges for many species of animals. Ahead you will find other refuges used by animals to escape the mid-day sun.
audioDescription: A singular large leafy tree with rough bark shading over a dried up streambed.

title: Sound of Silence Trail Stop 4

images.altText: A dried up streambed with channels moving through the sandy soil.
images.title: Sound of Silence Streambed
images.caption: Large sections of the Sound of Silence trail move along dried up streambeds.

bodyText: Take a close look at the earthen bank on your right for evidence of flowing water — sometimes swift and other times slow. Faster water can carry larger particles. Can you find a layer that was accompanied by the sound of rushing water? Slower water can only carry fine sediments. Try to find a layer that would have been deposited by a quiet trickle. The surrounding cliffs, slowly eroded by wind and water, add to the diverse, sorted sediment layers. Erosion continues with each new rainstorm moving more sediment downstream. Differences in the sediment layers help natural cavities develop. Holes may be enlarged and used by squirrels and birds, as nesting sites. Listen carefully and you may hear the scratchy call of a Rock Wren or the melodic song of a Canyon Wren. Look carefully and you may see a Golden-mantled Ground Squirrel peeking out of a hole, its high pitched alarm call warning others of your presence.
audioDescription: A dried up streambed with channels moving through the sandy soil.

title: Sound of Silence Trail Stop 5

images.altText: A large close up of beige colored sandstone pointing skywards.
images.title: Nugget Sandstone
images.caption: Nugget Sandstone formed from windblown sand dunes in a vast desert.

bodyText: The rounded bluffs of Nugget Sandstone towering above you are remnants of a vast desert that once covered much of what is now the western United States. Thin diagonal layers called cross-beds formed as wind blown sand dunes moved across the desert 200 million years ago. The steep fronts of these dunes were hundreds of feet high. Trace fossils in the Nugget Sandstone include the tracks of scorpions, spiders, and Brasilichnium, an early relative of mammals. Bones from an early Triassic dinosaur have also been found in this rock layer.
audioDescription: A large close up of beige colored sandstone pointing skywards.

title: Sound of Silence Trail Stop 6

images.altText: A close up image of grayish-green foliage on a shrub with dry desert scenery in the backdrop.
images.title: Sagebrush
images.caption: Many plants in Dinosaur has special adaptations to survive in the cold desert.

bodyText: Enjoy the view as you study the plants growing all around you. Does the pattern of their placement say anything to you? The bench of land you are on overlooks a riparian area, filled with Fremont Cottonwood trees growing where water is more plentiful and soil is deeper. On the rocky ledges above are junipers, which can survive on very little water. In between, where you are now, are shrubs like greasewood and sage. Many vegetation patterns occur throughout Dinosaur National Monument, influenced by elevation, amount of water, minerals in the soils, or sunlight. In turn, these zones provide a variety of unique habitats for wildlife.
audioDescription: A close up image of grayish-green foliage on a shrub with dry desert scenery in the backdrop.

title: Sound of Silence Trail Stop 7

images.altText: An overhanging sandstone rock formation which shades a small offshoot from a dirt trail.
images.title: Packrat Shelter
images.caption: Packrats shelter themselves amongst the shade of the boulders.

bodyText:
Within this shady rock overhang, can you spot a portion of a packrat debris pile, also known as a midden? It is above your head, in the crevice between the two large rocks that form the overhang. Look for twigs, rocks and fecal pellets, all held together by shiny crystallized urine. Middens can tell us about past environments. They may exist and be added to for thousands of years. Radiocarbon dating has identified middens up to 50,000 years old. Middens may contain leaves, seeds, fruit, twigs, pollen, bone, shells and scales, leading to identification of past environments. We know from middens that Douglas Fir and Ponderosa Pine once grew in this area, during a cooler and wetter time. As the climate changed over the last 10,000 years, these species retreated to higher elevations where they are still found.

You may notice some plant stumps with large root structures. Why would monument staff cut down these plants? Look around for the feathery leaves of tamarisk, also known as salt cedar. If it is blooming, it will have small, white to pink flowers. It is a non-native tree that grows in riparian areas. Brought to North America in the early 19th century for use as an ornamental wind break, and to fight erosion, it quickly spread and became an invasive weed, often outcompeting native plants. Its presence on the river banks of the Green and Yampa Rivers, and here in this intermittent stream, changes river flow and makes it difficult for deer, elk, and sheep to get to water. In 2006 and 2007, Dinosaur National Monument introduced
50,000 non-native northern tamarisk beetles to four locations in the monument. The most intensively studied biocontrol agent in North America, the beetle eats only tamarisk. While tamarisk will never be eliminated entirely, the beetles are helping to keep it under control and allow native vegetation to rebound.
audioDescription: An overhanging sandstone rock formation which shades a small offshoot from a dirt trail. There are many desert shrubs and trees growing around it.

title: Sound of Silence Trail Stop 8

images.altText: A large sandstone bluff rising high above a dry desert streambed.
images.title: Peregrine Falcon Nest Site
images.caption: Peregrine Falcons are know to nest atop the high sandstone cliffs.

bodyText: While native plants like the greasewood, rabbitbrush, and sage are important habitat, what about the rock walls themselves? The large cliff to the south has, in past years, been the nesting place of Peregrine Falcons. Once an endangered species, their numbers have now grown. Thanks to a ban on the pesticide DDT, and protected nesting places like this cliff face in Dinosaur National Monument, you may see a Peregrine Falcon soaring overhead. Listen carefully for the highpitched “kak, kak, kak” call.
audioDescription: A large sandstone bluff rising high above a dry desert streambed.

title: Sound of Silence Trail Stop 9

images.altText: A triangular flat rock with wavy patterns embedded throughout.
images.title: Moenkopi Ripple Rock
images.caption: The rocks of the Moenkopi are remnants of a shallow sea.

bodyText: Hidden within these hills are clues of their origin. Look for ripple marks on some of the rocks, and imagine the lapping sound of waves, a message from the past. You are now walking through the remains of a shallow, watery environment from 250 million years ago called the Moenkopi Formation. Muds and sands were deposited in thin beds on the edges and bottoms of watery areas. Reptiles and amphibians moved stealthily along shorelines and through these shallow waters, in a time before the dinosaurs. Invertebrates burrowed in the muds of the floodplains, and ammonites (a type of mollusk) swam in the seaways. Although the weathered soils of the Moenkopi Formation may look inhospitable, flowering plants like Desert Paintbrush, Pale Evening Primrose and the dramatic Prince’s Plume grow here. What are these plants telling us? These soils are high in selenium, which the Prince’s Plume utilizes so that it is unpalatable and even toxic if consumed.
audioDescription: A triangular flat rock with wavy patterns embedded throughout.

title: Split Mountain Anticline

images.altText: Large sandstone rock faces, adjacent to a dirt hiking trail, tilted upward with rugged scenery.
images.title: Split Mountain Anticline
images.caption: The Fossil Discovery Trail passes through various tilted rocks.

bodyText: As you begin your hike, take a moment to notice the dramatic tilt of the rock layers around you. These were once horizontal layers of sediment that eventually turned into flat-lying sedimentary rock, with older layers at the bottom and younger on top. Between 50-70 million years ago, the rocks here were uplifted and folded into an arch, or anticline. Since then, much of the top of the anticline has eroded away, and what you'll hike through today are the younger layers flanking the anticline's south side.
audioDescription: Large sandstone rock faces, adjacent to a dirt hiking trail, tilted upward with rugged scenery.

title: Split Mountain Overlook
listingDescription: The Split Mountain Overlook is along the self-guided auto tour: Tour of the Tilted Rocks.

images.altText: A panoramic view from a roadside pullout of a river flowing at the base of a desert mountain.
images.title: Split Mountain Overlook
images.caption: The Split Mountain Overlook sits above a staggering geologic view.

bodyText: From the Split Mountain Overlook, one can look out across the landscape that is under constant change. Below the cottonwood groves of the Split Mountain Campground shade the ever shifting banks along the Green River. Across the water, Dinosaur's staggering geologic history is on full display as multiple layers of rock have been tilted upwards, with some older rock exposures dating well back to 300 million years ago.
audioDescription: A panoramic view from a roadside pullout of a river flowing past cottonwood trees at the base of a large rocky mountain jutting out from desert scenery.

title: Stegosaurus ungulates
listingDescription: Stegosaurus is a plant eating dinosaur with plates on its back and spikes on its tail. Stegosaurus ungulatus is a species of ornithischian dinosaur from the Late Jurassic of North America, found in the Morrison Formation. Stegosaurus means “roofed lizard,” a reference to its plates.

images.altText: A four legged dinosaur with plates on its back and spikes on its tail.
images.title: Stegosaurus ungulates
images.caption: The most complete juvenile Stegosaurus was found in the Carnegie Quarry.

bodyText:
Stegosaurus is a plant eating dinosaur with plates on its back and spikes on its tail. Stegosaurus ungulatus is a species of ornithischian dinosaur from the Late Jurassic of North America, found in the Morrison Formation. Stegosaurus means “roofed lizard,” a reference to its plates. The function of these plates has been debated by paleontologists. One theory is that the plates contained blood vessels, to help regulate body temperature. Another idea is the plates were used for display to attract mates, like colorful feathers on a bird or antlers on a deer. The plates also could have been used for protection from predators. Since the plates were not directly attached to the bones of the skeleton, they were easily separated from the body after death. Massive spikes on the end of its tail were used in defense against predators. At Dinosaur, many isolated plates and spikes have been found throughout the Carnegie Quarry.

Stegosaurus is one of the most easily recognized dinosaurs of the Jurassic. The plates on its back and spikes on its tail make it one of the most unique creatures of the Mesozoic (Age of Dinosaurs). The Carnegie Quarry is so rich in fossils that multiple skeletons have been mounted from early excavations at Dinosaur.

In 1977 paleontologists at Dinosaur National Monument removed a juvenile Stegosaurus from the Carnegie Quarry face. They found limb bones, shoulder blades, most of the hips, some ribs, and skull fragments. Since plates were not found, it is unknown if juveniles had them at all. However, these fossils make up the most complete juvenile Stegosaurus ever found. A mounted cast of the fragile bones ison display at the Quarry Exhibit Hall.

title: Stump Formation

images.altText: A small pocket knife on a rock face covered in clam shell fossils.
images.title: Stump Formation Fossils
images.caption: Many of the Stump Formation fossils are small in size.

bodyText: At the end of this trail spur you will have traveled to 161-156 million years ago when this area was part of a large inland sea. The Stump Formation reveals evidence of an ocean environment with a large variety of life. Fossils in these rocks include belemnites (squid-like sea creatures), snails, ammonites, and bones of ichthyosaurs (a giant marine reptile that resembled a modern dolphin). Find and feel many small indentations and bumps on the large rocks on the ground. These are impressions of saltwater clams.
audioDescription: Large fallen rocks and boulders lain across the end of a trail, covered with impression of small clam fossils.

title: Sunrise Overlook
listingDescription: Sunrise Overlook is a small roadside pullout with stunning views of the Uinta Basin.

images.altText: A roadside pullout with a view of a vast plateau.
images.title: Sunrise Overlook
images.caption: The view from Sunrise overlooks the Colorado Plateau.

bodyText:
About 4 miles north of the Canyon Visitor Center, stop at the pullout on the right. Here, you can view a layer of deep red mudstone sandwiched between two lightercolored sandstones. This feature reminded an early traveler of a derby hat and inspired the name Plug Hat Butte, with a “crown” of Entrada Sandstone and a “band” of red Carmel Formation. As you drive around the butte, look for sweeping cross-beds of fine sand grains in the “brim” of Nugget Sandstone, indicating that this rock layer began as windblown desert sand dunes.

At the Plug Hat Butte picnic area, several viewpoints and short walks introduce you to the Colorado Plateau. Sedimentary rock layers across Colorado, Utah, New Mexico, and Arizona were uplifted to form a table-like region, or plateau, drained by the Colorado River and its tributaries. The scene before you is typical of the plateau’s colorful strata, flat topped mesas, buttes, and sheer walled canyons. Lack of soil and plant cover contributes to the visibility of these landforms.
audioDescription: An unnamed roadside pullout with an overlook of a vast plateau.

title: Swelter Shelter Petroglyphs
listingDescription: Numerous petroglyph or rock art sites left by the Fremont Culture dot Dinosaur National Monument. Swelter Shelter is the most accessible since it is located approximately one mile from the Quarry Visitor Center.

images.altText: A large rock face with a variety of designs etched into the rock.
images.title: Swelter Shelter Petroglyph Site
images.caption: Petroglyphs and pictographs left by the Fremont cover rock faces at the Swelter Shelter site.

bodyText:
Located approximately 1 mile (1.6 km) from the Quarry Visitor Center, the Swelter Shelter site features a variety of both petroglyphs and pictographs, designed by the Fremont Culture. The site is an easy walk, approximately 200 feet (61 m) from the parking area.

Don't touch! Petroglyphs and pictographs are fragile, irreplaceable records of the past that many still hold sacred. Touching them can leave skin oils behind, and tracings or rubbings can ruin the designs. Federal law protects all artifacts, including these sites. Do your part to respect and protect the past, and report any vandalism you find.
audioDescription: A large cliff looms above the site. On the rock face, a number of designs are etched into the rock. Some resemble humanoid shapes and others look like animals. Some designs have red coloration applied to them.

title: The Gates of Lodore

images.altText: A fast flowing river, rushing through a steep, reddish desert canyon.
images.title: Disaster Falls
images.caption: The scenery of Lodore is rugged and beautiful.

bodyText:
“How does the water Come down at Lodore?” My little boy asked me thus, once on a time; and moreover he tasked me to tell him in rhyme. Anon, at the word, there first came one daughter, and then came another, to second and third the request of their brother, and to hear how the water comes down at Lodore, with its rush and its roar, as many a time they had seen it before. So I told them in rhyme, for of rhymes I had store; and ‘twas in my vocation for their recreation that so I should sing; because I was laureate to them and the king. From its sources which well In the tarn on the fell; from its fountains In the mountains, its rills and its gills; through moss and through brake, it runs and it creeps for a while, till it sleeps In its own little lake. And thence at departing, awakening and starting, it runs through the reeds, and away it proceeds, through meadow and glade, in sun and in shade, and through the wood-shelter, among crags in its flurry, helter-skelter, hurry-skurry. Here it comes sparkling, and there it lies darkling; now smoking and frothing Its tumult and wrath in, till, in this rapid race on which it is bent, it reaches the place of its steep descent.”

Excerpt from “ The Catarct of Lodore” by Robert Southey
audioDescription: A steep, rugged river canyon, surrounded by desert shrubland scenery.

title: Torvosaurus tanneri
listingDescription: Torvosaurus tanneri is a species of theropod dinosaur from the Late Jurassic Morrison Formation of North America. It is known from the Carnegie Quarry at Dinosaur National Monument from a single bone, the humerus. This upper arm bone is more robust and straighter than its more common contemporary, Allosaurus. Torvosaurus was likely the largest theropod in the Morrison Formation.

images.altText: A large carnivorous dinosaur with sharp teeth.
images.title: Torvosaurus tanneri
images.caption: Torvosaurus was one of the largest carnivores of its time, the true terror of the Jurassic.

bodyText: Torvosaurus tanneri is a species of theropod dinosaur from the Late Jurassic Morrison Formation of North America. A small section of vertebrae from Torvosaurus was uncovered from Dinosaur National Monument during excavations of the Carnegie Quarry in the early 1900s. Today, this vertebrae is now in the Denver Museum of Nature and Science. Torvosaurus was likely the largest theropod in the Morrison Formation.

title: Tour of the Tilted Rocks Stop #3

images.altText: A small shrub-like tree in a desert landscape with a large sandstone mountain as the backdrop.
images.title: Utah Juniper
images.caption: Junipers cover a significant portion of the monument's landscape.

bodyText: The Utah Juniper is a hardy tree that thrives in environments where other plants would find it difficult to take root. Able to withstand intense heat, fierce cold, overbearing sunlight, extreme lack of water, and blasting winds, the juniper provides an important source of food and shelter for desert dwellers.
audioDescription: A roadside pullout looking towards a large expanse of desert scenery, dotted with juniper trees and bushes while a large sandstone mountain sits in the backdrop.

title: Tour of the Tilted Rocks Stop #4

images.altText: A roadside pullout looking downhill towards a large mountain surrounded by desert rock formations.
images.title: Tilted Rocks
images.caption: The monuments titled rock scenery is a result of geologic uplift.

bodyText: The tilt and colors of the rocks are the most noticeable features of the landscape. Each rock layer was formed in a certain environment at a specific time. Geologists call those discrete layers formations. The formation on either side of the road here formed in streams and rivers during the late Triassic Period, resulting in a coarse-grained, gritty yellow and tan sandstone. Utah is famous for red rocks which contain oxidized iron minerals that were exposed to air. Often nearby there are green rocks that are reduced iron minerals which altered in water. The yellow colors in the sandstone right here are also result from a mixture of materials, including iron oxides, sulfides, and silicates, called limonite.
audioDescription: A roadside pullout looking downhill towards a large mountain surrounded by desert rock formations that have been tilted upward.

title: Tour of the Tilted Rocks Stop #7

images.altText: A roadside pullout looking across a field towards a long hillside with vibrant purple, red, and gray
images.title: Morrison Formation
images.caption: Morrison Formation dates back to the Late Jurassic Period 150 million years ago.

bodyText: The distinctively colorful layers help to identify the Morrison Formation, a group of rock layers that occur throughout this region. Paleontologists find this rock attractive for more than its colors; a few of its outcrops contain 150 million year old dinosaur fossils like those found at the Dinosaur Quarry. The formation originated as muds and sands laid down by a network of ancient rivers whose water nourished an abundance of plants, dinosaurs, and other animals. It is thought that during times of drought the river would dry up and there would be massive die-offs. Dinosaur carcasses collected in the river bed. When the rains returned, the river flowed again and transported bones and carcasses then buried them in sand and mud where they were preserved.
audioDescription: A roadside pullout looking across a field towards a long hillside with vibrant purple, red, and gray bands.

title: Tour of the Tilted Rocks Stop #9

images.altText: A dirt road turning off from the pavement leading towards a canyon with petroglyphs on the walls.
images.title: Petroglyph Pullout
images.caption: When driving to and from the petroglyph site, remember to leave all gates as you found them.

bodyText: The road to the right will take you outside of Dinosaur National Monument, crossing private property. You will pass through two gates. The road will lead you to a fenced petroglyph site protected by the Bureau of Land Management. This site is of a similar time and style to petroglyphs found throughout the monument. When driving to and from the petroglyph site, remember to leave all gates as you found them. If you open a gate, close it behind you.
audioDescription: A dirt road turning off from the pavement leading towards a canyon with petroglyphs on the walls.

title: Turtle Rock
listingDescription: Turtle Rock is a large Entrada Sandstone formation along Cub Creek Road.

images.altText: A large sandstone rock formation resembling a turtle.
images.title: Turtle Rock
images.caption: Turtle Rock overlooks Cub Creek Road as it winds through the monument.

bodyText: From long-time settlers to brief passers-by, many of us like to name what we see around us. This towering outcropping of Entrada Sandstone, the same tye of rock that forms arches in Arches National Park, is known as Turtle Rock. Can you see the turtle poking its head out from the flat shell?
audioDescription: A large sandstone rock formation in the shape of a turtle.

title: Upper Canyon Overlook
listingDescription: The Upper Canyon Overlook also provides views of Round Top Mountain.

images.altText: A vista atop a high plateau overlooking a canyon.
images.title: Upper Canyon Overlook
images.caption: The Upper Canyon Overlook stands in the shadow of Round Top Mountain, overlooking the canyon area.

bodyText: Off to the right of the overlook, you can see Round Top Mountain, which is home to a fire lookout tower staffed during the summer. Summer thunderstorms keep the lookout busy reporting “smokes” produced by lightning strikes. Fire plays a natural role in the ecosystem and helps maintain a healthy diversity of plant and animal life. The goal of fire management at Dinosaur is to mimic the frequency, timing, and size of fires as they would have occurred prior to the late 1800s.
audioDescription: A high overlook viewing a vast plateau with a few pine and juniper trees in the near distance.

title: Vivas Cake Hill Overlook

images.altText: A roadside overlook with a view of a dirt road winding down into a canyon.
images.title: Vivas Cake Hill Overlook
images.caption: The Vivas Cake Hill Overlook is seeped in homesteading history.

bodyText:
There is a good chance that you will see cattle along the road, and may even encounter local ranchers driving their herds to better pasture. Over the last century, grazing has been a primary use of the land in and around Dinosaur National Monument. Today, grazing is still allowed at certain locations within the monument’s boundary. Many of the families permitted to pasture their animals here originally homesteaded in the area in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, prior to the establishment of the monument.

In those days, cattle rustling was a common trade in this part of the country. Trail Draw, the small canyon before you, was part of what is now known as the Outlaw Trail. This famous backcountry route snaked through desolate, rugged terrain from Montana to New Mexico, linking well-known hideouts such as Hole in the Wall and Robber’s Roost. The most notorious outlaws that used this route were known as the Wild Bunch, led by Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid. Legend holds that the infamous duo originally met in Browns Park, an area just north of the monument. Abundant grasslands and relatively warm winters attracted settlers to Browns Park as early as the 1870s. Outlaws frequented this isolated valley to rest and resupply.

Two local residents, Ann and Josie, also known as the Bassett sisters, befriended the Wild Bunch. The Bassett family was on good terms with the outlaws, and even joined them for a Thanksgiving dinner, alongside other residents of the valley. Their friendship with the Wild Bunch may have deterred other local outlaws from rustling the Bassett’s cattle. Eventually, Josie moved to the base of Split Mountain where her homestead still stands today.
audioDescription: A roadside overlook with a view of a dirt road winding down into a canyon.

title: Wagon Wheel Overlook
listingDescription: Wagon Wheel Point Overlook provides stunning views of the Yampa River as it carves through the river canyons.

images.altText: A high vista overlooking a sandstone river canyon.
images.title: Wagon Wheel Overlook
images.caption: Nestled along the remote Yampa Bench, the Wagon Wheel Overlook provides stunning vistas.

bodyText:
From the Wagon Wheel Overlook you can look out across the Yampa River as it winds its way through dramatic weber sandstone canyons. To access the overlook, visitors must drive along the Yampa Bench Road which requires high clearance and 4x4 capability. The overlook is a short walk off of the pullout area.

Use caution when exploring the vista point as this is not a developed overlook.
audioDescription: An overlook high atop a sandstone cliff looking out across a twisting river canyon.
